data.title: Julie Dash Tells the Story Behind the Making of 'Daughters of the Dust'
data.meta_description: "I was very excited by the opportunity to depict African-American women, or women from the African diaspora, in a way that was different from what I was seeing on television at the time or what I saw in blaxploitation films," says Dash.Director: Courtney Yates @courtsyyDP: Rachel Batashvili @rachelbatashviliEditor: Tajah Smith @tajahmsmith_Producer: Nicola PardyAssociate Producer: Qieara LesesneEntertainment Director, Vogue: Sergio KletnoyPost-Production Supervisor: Marco GlinbizziFilmed on Location: The Mark Hotel
data.text:
When I found out that Beyonce's Lemonade

had some elements of Daughters of the Dust,

my website shut down,

and then I started getting all these phone calls and emails.

Have you seen it?

People started asking me...

[stammers]

Were you offended or anything?

I was like, No! [chuckles]

Are you kidding?

Hi, Vogue.

I'm Julie Dash, and I'm here to talk to you about my film

Daughters of the Dust.

[girls clapping] [soft music]

[film reel clicking]

[film reel clicking]

[film reel clicking]

I started studying film doing the Blaxploitation period.

When I was in high school, as I say,

I started going to the Studio Museum of Harlem,

and studying cinematography.

Later, when I was in undergraduate school at CCNY,

a pilot program called the Leonard Davis Center

for the Performing Arts was started.

So I decided to change my major and major in film.

I relocated out to Los Angeles.

I wrote and directed a film called Illusions in 1982.

I think I did another film, short film called Four Women.

But all the time I'd been writing and perfecting,

and making a trailer for Daughters of the Dust,

and then eventually we were able to raise $800,000.

[camera shutter clicking]

[Man] Nana, she carried them with her for generations.

Daughters of the dust is about a African American family,

about the women who are the carriers

of their traditions and belief.

And it's a family dinner that takes place

the night before they migrate north.

I was very much excited by the opportunity

to depict African American women,

or women from the African diaspora,

in a way that was different

from what I was seeing on television at the time,

or what I was seeing in the movies

with the Blaxploitation films.

I always felt that other,

the stories of others were told

with such elegance and grace,

and our stories were just kind of like, brutal.

And so, I was determined to reimagine

how we are on the screen in historical drama,

as well as contemporary life

in a way that showed respect for my family

and for the community from which I came, you know?

[camera shutter clicking]

The costumes were very, very particular for me.

And one of the things that we did with the costumes,

what I wanted was

to have the costumes indicate to the viewer the time period

and where these women were in their lives

and how this family functioned on this island.

So I made sure that all of the costumes

were 10 to 15 years older

than the 1902 time period in which it's set.

They were like Gibson girl, white dresses.

But if you know anything about the Gibson girl dresses,

they were hand me downs.

In the late 1800s,

Gibson girl dress was just something

that was fashionable and in Sears catalogs.

So then you know that there was some contact

with the outside world, with wealthier families

who handed these things down,

and these women wore it on special days.

It was also important for me to show that African Americans

are not always wearing the same old,

the clothing that they wear

when they're doing agricultural work,

because that's usually what we see.

It was also important that I indicate that the Nana Peazant,

the family matriarch,

that she's not wearing one of these white dresses.

She's wearing a dress

that's dyed in indigo blue specifically,

because that was the cash crop that they worked on

when she was growing up.

The color indigo, it's very important,

and remains very important to the Gullah Geechee people

'cause it was not only a cash crop in the colonies.

It was also technology and agriculture

that they brought with them from West Africa,

the process, the planting, harvesting,

and processing of indigo.

And so that's something that we still see today,

painted on the windows and framing houses, the color indigo.

It's just very special and very powerful, very magical.

The wardrobe team, they were fantastic.

We had several things that were built in Savannah,

like Yellow Mary's dress was made handmade in Savannah.

The most important thing about the costumes were,

we had to age them

because it's very difficult to shoot white

on black skin tones.

And we didn't want that contrast out there

especially because the sun was so bright,

and the sand was so bright white,

and with the bright white dresses,

it would've been, you know, catastrophic.

So everything was like, dipped in,

they call it dipped in tea

but really, it was dipped in dye

to bring down the whiteness

and make it appear more aesthetically pleasing to the eye

on the dark skin tones.

Between myself and Kerry James Marshall,

who was our production designer,

we worked very hard on establishing a look,

creating a world that was unlike any world

that had been seen before on the screen.

The costumes were from actual photographs

that were held at the Penn Center:

photographs of women in white dresses

having lunch on the beach.

They also wore hats, but we could not afford the hats.

[chuckles] We ran out of money.

[camera shutter clicking]

We submitted to Sundance and they accepted it.

It was in the competition.

We won for best cinematography,

and we assumed that we would get distribution right away,

but we did not get distribution.

It wasn't until one year later,

and it was released to theaters in 1992.

It just never occurred to me until someone said,

Well, you're the first Black woman

to get a major theatrical release.

It was kind of bittersweet

because it was like, this is 1992.

There were some distributors

who didn't even want to talk about it.

They wanted to see what they normally see, you know,

in Black people, in situations, and in locations

where they were recognizable from previous films.

And at the time, you know,

Black youth films, you know

male-oriented, dominated youth films were being made,

and they wanted to see something more hip-hop.

And I was actually told by, you know,

one distributor that my film was not authentic

like the other films were.

In terms of depicting African Americans on a screen,

it was mostly stories about antebellum,

slavery period, and all of that,

or what I call the urban testosterone films.

We had this hunger, you know,

to see ourselves as complicated people living our lives

and everything didn't have to do

with racial oppression or civil rights.

I did not know the way I was dressing the characters

in Daughters of the Dust

would be surprising or shocking to most.

Some people would say they were just absolutely offended.

Daily Variety said that

it looked like a Laura Ashley commercial

because of the white dresses,

and then that, right there.

you could just see that's the biased attitude.

It's like why,

if you're thinking of having black women depicted

at the turn of this century,

they have no right to be wearing a white dress

blowing in the wind, in the sand.

They need to have a pitchfork and a hoe.

They were saying, you know,

like, Black people don't wear white dresses like that.

You know, Why didn't they have on

a playa dress or something?

And that just goes to show you that

we see so much of the same thing over and over in television

and in motion pictures.

Not so much now, as it was 30 years ago

[camera shutter clicking]

Daughters of the Dust has had a long life. [chuckles]

And so I'm very happy, all very happy about that.

I've had a lot of comments from a lot of young filmmakers

who say, you know, it was one of the first Black films

that they've seen like that,

that even though they didn't understand it,

they can't get it out of their mind.

When I found out that Beyonce's Lemonade

had some elements of Daughters of the Dust,

my website shut down,

and then I started getting all these phone calls and emails.

Have you seen it?

And at that time, I had to get a link.

Like I was in awe, it was beautiful.

I just watched it.

My mouth was open agape,

and I was just watched this whole thing for 40 minutes.

It was like, my heart was beating so hard.

It was so good.

And then, the interesting thing was then,

people started asking me,

[stammers]

Were you offended or anything?

It was like, No! [chuckles]

Are you kidding?

I went to art school. [chuckles]

We don't get, with that, we love stuff like that.

It's like, you know,

next generation takes your stuff and repurposes it.

And that's the whole meaning of telling stories.

There's a continuum of ideas that build on projects.

There's nothing that's like, totally, totally original.

And I've told people many times

that my tree scene was homage to Ganja & Hess,

with Dr. Hess sitting in their legs swinging.

I've been influenced and informed

by other pieces of artwork

that kind of speak to that time period.

I think Daughters of the Dust

has had the impact that it's had because it's different,

because it went beyond the comfort zone of most,

because it introduced Gullah Geechee culture

to the mainstream African American culture,

because we dared to light it in a certain way,

AJ's lighting,

because Kerry James Marshall's production design

was so authentic and confounding,

and the music of John Barnes.

So I think it was a combination of all of these things

that make it, still make it kind of an interesting film

to look back at.

[soft music]
